title: Auditors question The Agency's ability to continue operations
text:
The future of The Agency is in limbo after an auditor's qualified audit report over its latest annual results questioned the company's ability to continue operations following another round of loss and poor cash flow.

The ASX-listed real estate firm this week reported a net loss of $7.83 million for the year ending June 30 in financial statements that caused auditor Bentleys to raise concerns about its ability to continue as a "going concern".

The Agency's managing director Paul Niardone with chief executive Matt Lahood. Supplied

The group incurred a net cash outflow of $6.4 million against last year's outflows of $2.3 million and has a working capital deficit of $28.3 million. The only way the company has been able to continue its business is through a series of capital raisings from current shareholders and new investors, including Magnolia Capital and Honan Insurance Group.

"These events or conditions ... indicate that a material uncertainty exists that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. Our opinion is not modified in respect of this matter," Bentleys partner Mark Delaurentis said in the company's Independent Auditor's Report.

Aside from losses, the company also flagged it had structured "payment plans" with the Australian Taxation Office and said it would only be able to continue its business through more "support" from its creditors and suppliers, on top of raising more capital.
description: The business reported a net loss of $7.83 million for the year, causing auditor Bentleys to issue a qualified audit report.
